template.name: FreeBSD Core Temp
template.description: ## Description Monitor core temperature of Intel CPUs. The 'coretemp' kernel module must be loaded. ## Overview ### Update: there's an amdtemp module in FreeBSD kernel, similar to coretemp. So this should work on AMD processors, too! 1) load [coretemp kernel module](https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?coretemp): **kldload coretemp** (for Intel CPUs) or [amdtemp kernel module](https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=amdtemp): **kldload amdtemp** (for AMD CPUs) 2) add **coretemp\_load="YES"** or **amdtemp\_load="YES"** to **/boot/loader.conf** 3) create **userparameter\_coretemp.conf** file in zabbix\_agentd.conf.d, *** make sure you have bash installed and the Include directive is present and valid in zabbix\_agentd.conf to include individual files *** ``` UserParameter=coretemp.cpu.discovery, /usr/local/bin/bash -c 'echo -n "{\"data\":["; for i in `sysctl -a | grep "dev.cpu.*.temperature" | awk -F "." '\''{print $3}'\'' | sort -n` ; do echo -n "{\"{#CPUCORE}\":\""$i"\"}," ; done | sed "s/.$//"; echo -n "]}"' ``` ``` UserParameter=coretemp.cpu[*], sysctl dev.cpu.$1.temperature | sed 's/.$//' | awk '{print $NF}' ``` 4) restart zabbix\_agentd, import & apply the template 5) also make sure zabbix\_agentd has all the paths needed: in **/etc/rc.conf** ``` zabbix\_agentd\_paths="/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin" ``` ## Author Felicián Hoppál
